Dear Si,
Your letter of Sept. 25, saying "-I am completely
behind on what has gone on.T* disturbs me a bit. On Sept. 17
I wrote you a four page letter which I thought you'd get
immediately upon your return and which was designed to bring
you up to date. I have sent a number of carbons of other
correspondence which were intended to further fill you in
on details. I*to enclosing my file copy of the letter of
Sept. 17, just in case you did not get the original. I± you
did get it and -didn't read it, you've not a damned thing to
yell about so I've no remorse and-no smypathy for you.
Glad your trip was exciting and fruitful. I shall be most
eager to get more details.
The "committee" which you asked about was the one
I named, after conferring with every member of the board,
to screen the list and arrive at one name to recommend to
the Board for the job of Executive Director. I named Burton,
Allen, and myself to that committee for a number of reasons
and upon the advice of most of the Board. Dunn was named
by one member as his suggestion, but the letter to Schramm
was reason enough for not putting him on. Hull, Schooley,
and Schramm were in Urbana, and Jim, so all of us worked
on the list. Wilbur and I flew to BattleCreek one after¬
noon for a conference with Masters and VanDuyn.
I think Wynn is our best bet, but we need a
conference with him. I*11 talk to Burton Monday and then
set up the meeting in Washington on the evening of the
16th. and the morning of the 17th. if he feels as the
others do that it should be held. Please keep that time
free on your calendar if possible.
If anything else comes up you need to know
about_concerning anything that happened while you we re
away, please call me or write. We are supposed to be
specialists in communications, but our biggest problem
seems to be failure to communicate adequately.
Best always,
Graydon
MEMBER OF NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
